elements.content: Mesoporous Zn4O­(−COO)6-based metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), including UMCM-1, MOF-205, MUF-7a, and the newly synthesized MOFs, termed ST-1, ST-2, ST-3, and ST-4 (ST = ShanghaiTech University), have been systematically investigated for ultrahigh capacity methane storage. Exceptionally, ST-2 was found to have the highest deliverable capacity of 289 cm3 STP/cm3 (567 mg/g) at 298 K and 5–200 bar, which surpasses all previously reported records held by porous materials. We illustrate that the fine-tuned mesoporosity is critical in further improving the deliverable capacities at ultrahigh pressure.
elements.clean_text:
Mesoporous
Zn4O­(−COO)6-based metal–organic
frameworks (MOFs), including UMCM-1, MOF-205, MUF-7a, and the newly
synthesized MOFs, termed ST-1, ST-2, ST-3, and ST-4 (ST = ShanghaiTech
University), have been systematically investigated for ultrahigh capacity
methane storage. Exceptionally, ST-2 was found to have the highest
deliverable capacity of 289 cm3
STP/cm3 (567 mg/g) at 298 K and 5–200 bar, which surpasses all previously
reported records held by porous materials. We illustrate that the
fine-tuned mesoporosity is critical in further improving the deliverable
capacities at ultrahigh pressure.

elements.content: Tremendous efforts have been made to design superior porous materials for on-board methane storage to cut off CO2 emission from vehicles, an immediate solution for mitigating climate change. Integrating both inorganic clusters and organic struts, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are known for their diverse topologies, which codes for specific pore hierarchy, diverse pore geometries, and spatial arrangements of adsorption sites. As such, MOF structures offer exclusive opportunities for the manipulation of both host–guest interactions as well as guest–guest arrangements to boost the methane uptake at 298 K and relative lower pressure (e.g., 35 bar). Recently, prominent microporous MOFs, such as HKUST-1, MOF-5, UTSA-76, MOF-520, Co­(BDP), Al-soc-MOF-1, MAF-38, MOF-905, and MFM-115a were found to have high deliverable volumetric capacities when considering the retention of minimal inlet pressure (5 bar) with increased operational pressure (e.g., 65 or 80 bar). However, ultrahigh deliverable capacities, necessary for enabling applications in heavy-duty or long-haul vehicles, have yet to come to fruition. Herein, we targeted ultraporous MOFs possessing narrow mesopores (pore sizes < 4 nm), which have demonstrated drastically improved methane storage capacity at pressures up to 250 bar, conditions that are industrially viable for the adsorbed natural gas (ANG) applications.
elements.clean_text:
Tremendous efforts have been
made to design superior porous materials for on-board methane storage
to cut off CO2 emission from vehicles, an immediate solution
for mitigating climate change. Integrating both inorganic
clusters and organic struts, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs)
are known for their diverse topologies, which codes for specific pore
hierarchy, diverse pore geometries, and spatial arrangements of adsorption
sites. As such, MOF structures offer exclusive
opportunities for the manipulation of both host–guest interactions
as well as guest–guest arrangements to boost the methane uptake
at 298 K and relative lower pressure (e.g., 35 bar). Recently, prominent microporous MOFs, such as HKUST-1, MOF-5, UTSA-76, MOF-520, Co­(BDP), Al-soc-MOF-1, MAF-38, MOF-905, and MFM-115a were
found to have high deliverable volumetric capacities when considering
the retention of minimal inlet pressure (5 bar) with increased operational
pressure (e.g., 65 or 80 bar). However,
ultrahigh deliverable capacities, necessary for enabling applications
in heavy-duty or long-haul vehicles, have yet to come to fruition. Herein, we targeted ultraporous MOFs possessing
narrow mesopores (pore sizes < 4 nm), which have demonstrated drastically
improved methane storage capacity at pressures up to 250 bar, conditions
that are industrially viable for the adsorbed natural gas (ANG) applications.

elements.content: In order to maximize the deliverable capacity, the unusable methane uptake (<5 bar) must be suppressed. Thus, we chose to employ the Zn4O­(−COO)6 cluster, which possesses multiple adsorption sites with only moderate host–guest interactions. The synthetic strategy of mixing tritopic and ditopic linkers has proved worthwhile for accessing ultrahigh porosity without having to lengthen the organic struts in making mesoporous MOFs such as UMCM-1, MOF-205 (aka DUT-6), and MUF-7a ().
elements.clean_text:
In order to maximize the deliverable capacity,
the unusable methane
uptake (<5 bar) must be suppressed. Thus, we chose to employ the
Zn4O­(−COO)6 cluster, which possesses
multiple adsorption sites with only moderate host–guest interactions. The synthetic strategy of mixing tritopic and
ditopic linkers has proved worthwhile for accessing ultrahigh porosity
without having to lengthen the organic struts in making mesoporous
MOFs such as UMCM-1, MOF-205 (aka DUT-6), and MUF-7a ().

elements.clean_text:
1

Syntheses of Mesoporous
Zn4O­(−COO)6-Based
MOFs by Mixing Tritopic Linkers with Ditopic Linkers to Make Previously
Reported UMCM-1, MOF-205, MUF-7a, and the New MOFs Reported in This
Work

elements.content: To create diverse pore geometries for evaluating and correlating methane storage performance, we have synthesized a new series of mesoporous MOFs; namely, ST-1, ST-2, ST-3, and ST-4 (, ST = ShanghaiTech University), by mixing a tritopic linker, 4,4′,4″-s-triazine-1,3,5-triyltri-p-aminobenzoic acid (H3TATAB) with various ditopic linkers, including benzene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid (H2BDC), 2,6-naphthalene-dicarboxylic acid (H2NDC), biphenyl-4,4′-dicarboxylic acid (H2BPDC), and the combination of H2BDC and H2BPDC (). Their chemical compositions, crystal structures, and skeleton robustness were determined by elemental analyses, X-ray diffraction analyses, digested-solution 1H NMR spectroscopy, and thermal gravimetric analyses (Sections S1–S5 in , SI).
elements.clean_text:
To create diverse pore geometries
for evaluating and correlating
methane storage performance, we have synthesized a new series of mesoporous
MOFs; namely, ST-1, ST-2, ST-3, and ST-4 (, ST = ShanghaiTech University), by mixing
a tritopic linker, 4,4′,4″-s-triazine-1,3,5-triyltri-p-aminobenzoic acid (H3TATAB) with various ditopic
linkers, including benzene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid (H2BDC),
2,6-naphthalene-dicarboxylic acid (H2NDC), biphenyl-4,4′-dicarboxylic
acid (H2BPDC), and the combination of H2BDC
and H2BPDC (). Their chemical compositions, crystal structures, and skeleton
robustness were determined by elemental analyses, X-ray diffraction
analyses, digested-solution 1H NMR spectroscopy, and thermal
gravimetric analyses (Sections S1–S5 in , SI).

elements.content: As shown in , a systematic engineering of the pore geometries was achieved in the ST MOFs having similar compositions but diverse topologies. ST-1 (muo net) is composed of both 0-D cages ([43.56]; inner diameter: 2.2 × 2.2 × 1.5 nm3) and 1-D channels (inner diameter: 3.2 nm). ST-2 (umt net) features multiple varieties of cavities defined by (i) elongated polyhedral cages ([43.518]; inner diameter: 3.3 × 3.2 × 2.3 nm3); (ii) spherical icosahedral cages ([512]; inner diameter: 2.4 × 2.4 × 2.3 nm3); (iii) prolate polyhedral cages ([43.56]; inner diameter: 2.3 × 2.3 × 1.5 nm3), and (iv) adamantane-like cages ([54]; inner diameter: 0.8 nm). ST-3 (ith-d net) is unique in that it has an elongated pore shape ([512]; inner diameter: 3.2 × 3.0 × 2.7 nm3) with a BPDC vs BDC ratio of 2:1. As an exceptional case, ST-4 (ott net) is observed with colossal cages ([46.524.68], 3.0 nm +6 × 2.0 nm) terminated with dangling ligands, spherical mesoporous cages ([512.64]; inner diameter: 3.0 nm), cubic cages ([46]; inner diameter: 1.8 nm), and microporous adamantane-like cages ([54]; inner diameter: 1.0 nm). Notably, ST-2 and ST-4 represent a higher degree of complexity in conjunction with heterogeneity of pore structure.

As shown in , a systematic engineering of the pore geometries was
achieved in
the ST MOFs having similar compositions but diverse topologies. ST-1
(muo net) is composed of both 0-D cages ([43.56]; inner diameter: 2.2 × 2.2 × 1.5 nm3) and 1-D channels (inner diameter: 3.2 nm). ST-2 (umt net) features multiple varieties of cavities defined by (i) elongated
polyhedral cages ([43.518]; inner diameter:
3.3 × 3.2 × 2.3 nm3); (ii) spherical icosahedral
cages ([512]; inner diameter: 2.4 × 2.4 × 2.3
nm3); (iii) prolate polyhedral cages ([43.56]; inner diameter: 2.3 × 2.3 × 1.5 nm3), and (iv) adamantane-like cages ([54]; inner diameter:
0.8 nm). ST-3 (ith-d net) is unique in that it has an
elongated pore shape ([512]; inner diameter: 3.2 ×
3.0 × 2.7 nm3) with a BPDC vs BDC ratio of 2:1. As
an exceptional case, ST-4 (ott net) is observed with
colossal cages ([46.524.68], 3.0
nm +6 × 2.0 nm) terminated with dangling ligands, spherical mesoporous
cages ([512.64]; inner diameter: 3.0 nm), cubic
cages ([46]; inner diameter: 1.8 nm), and microporous adamantane-like
cages ([54]; inner diameter: 1.0 nm). Notably, ST-2 and
ST-4 represent a higher degree of complexity in conjunction with heterogeneity
of pore structure.

elements.content: Diverse topologies (noted with bold, lower case, three-letter symbols and related tiling descriptions; [...m n ...] describes a compartment having n faces that are m-membered rings) and various pore geometries (marked with their pore diameters) in the ST MOFs. Atom color codes: zinc, light blue polyhedron; oxygen, red; carbon, black; nitrogen, blue; hydrogen are omitted for clarity. The benzene rings of the TATAB linker are colored in pink; the benzene rings of the ditopic linkers are colored in light green or gray.

1

Diverse topologies (noted
with bold, lower case, three-letter symbols
and related tiling descriptions; [...m

n
...] describes a compartment having n faces that are m-membered rings) and various pore
geometries (marked with their pore diameters) in the ST MOFs. Atom
color codes: zinc, light blue polyhedron; oxygen, red; carbon, black;
nitrogen, blue; hydrogen are omitted for clarity. The benzene rings
of the TATAB linker are colored in pink; the benzene rings of the
ditopic linkers are colored in light green or gray.

elements.content: To evaluate their methane storage performance, the ST MOFs and relevant MOFs (MOF-5, UCMC-1, MOF-205, and MUF-7a) were all activated with optimized conditions (Section S6 in ). The ST MOFs represent high surface areas (up to 5660 m2/g), large pore volumes (up to 2.67 cm3/g), and fine-tuned pore size distributions (a and ) benefiting from the slightly longer tritopic linkers used and distinct topologies realized. According to established protocols, high-pressure (0–80 bar) methane uptake isotherms of MOF-5 can be well-reproduced in our lab (). As such (Section S7 in ), high uptakes with low unusual methane were observed in UMCM-1, MOF-205, and MUF-7a (b, bottom), to give relative high deliverable capacities (179–185 cm3 STP/cm3 for 5–80 bar). Interestingly, distinguishable methane uptakes were observed in the ST series (b, top) showing their dependence on the pore geometries. Higher volumetric deliverable capacity of 187 cm3 STP/cm3 was therefore realized by the ST-2 having multiple verities of mesopores and relative low isosteric heat of adsorption (Q st = 9.2 kJ mol–1; Section S8 in ). Simultaneously, both high volumetric and gravimetric deliverable capacities were achieved in the ST MOFs ().

with optimized conditions (Section S6 in ). The ST MOFs represent high surface areas (up to 5660 m2/g), large pore volumes (up to 2.67 cm3/g), and fine-tuned
pore size distributions (a and ) benefiting
from the slightly longer tritopic linkers used and distinct topologies
realized. According to established protocols, high-pressure (0–80 bar) methane uptake isotherms of MOF-5
can be well-reproduced in our lab (). As such (Section S7 in ), high uptakes
with low unusual methane were observed in UMCM-1, MOF-205, and MUF-7a
(b, bottom),
to give relative high deliverable capacities (179–185 cm3

st = 9.2
kJ mol–1; Section S8 in ). Simultaneously, both high volumetric and gravimetric deliverable
capacities were achieved in the ST MOFs ().

elements.content: (a) N2 physisorption isotherms at 77 K along with the pore size distributions (inset) derived from their Ar adsorption isotherms at 87 K for ST-1, ST-2, ST-3, and ST-4. (b) High-pressure (0–80 bar) methane uptake isotherms for the ST MOFs and their analogues at 298 K.
elements.clean_text:
2

(a) N2 physisorption isotherms
at 77 K along with the
pore size distributions (inset) derived from their Ar adsorption isotherms
at 87 K for ST-1, ST-2, ST-3, and ST-4. (b) High-pressure (0–80
bar) methane uptake isotherms for the ST MOFs and their analogues
at 298 K.

elements.content: By screening their ultrahigh-pressure methane uptakes via Grand canonical Monte Carlo (GCMC) simulation (Section S9 in ), the mesoporous Zn4O­(−COO)6-based MOFs are found to have higher deliverable methane uptakes at 298 K and 5–250 bar (). Significantly, ST MOFs enhance methane uptakes in the range of 80–250 bar (), which can be attributed to the engineered pore geometries and energy distribution (Section S10 in ). Thus, ST-2 is identified as the best material to have methane uptake as high as 324 cm3 STP/cm3 at 298 K and 250 bar, and the highest deliverable capacity of 305 cm3 STP/cm3 at 298 K and 5–250 bar.
elements.clean_text:
By screening their ultrahigh-pressure
methane uptakes via Grand
canonical Monte Carlo (GCMC) simulation (Section S9 in ), the mesoporous Zn4O­(−COO)6-based MOFs are found to have higher deliverable methane uptakes
at 298 K and 5–250 bar (). Significantly, ST MOFs enhance methane uptakes in the range of
80–250 bar (), which can be attributed to the engineered pore geometries and
energy distribution (Section S10 in ). Thus, ST-2 is identified as the best material
to have methane uptake as high as 324 cm3
STP/cm3 at 298 K and 250 bar, and the highest deliverable
capacity of 305 cm3
STP/cm3 at 298
K and 5–250 bar.

elements.content: Encouraged by these results, ultrahigh-pressure (0–200 bar) methane uptake isotherms of ST-2 were collected at 283, 298, and 308 K (a and Section S11 in ). Indeed, ultrahigh uptakes were observed in ST-2, which can store the same amount of methane at 130 bar and 298 K as that of the CNG process at 250 bar. More importantly, ultrahigh deliverable capacity of 289 cm3 STP/cm3 has been realized at 298 K and 5–200 bar, which can deliver 31% more than the compressed natrual gas (CNG) process at 200 bar and 12% more than the CNG process at 250 bar. Comparing with all the reported methane uptake data up to 200 bar (b and ), this performance is a new record in MOFs and surpasses the previous record holder of activated carbons.
elements.clean_text:
Encouraged by these results, ultrahigh-pressure
(0–200 bar)
methane uptake isotherms of ST-2 were collected at 283, 298, and 308
K (a and Section
S11 in ). Indeed, ultrahigh uptakes were
observed in ST-2, which can store the same amount of methane at 130
bar and 298 K as that of the CNG process at 250 bar. More importantly,
ultrahigh deliverable capacity of 289 cm3
STP/cm3 has been realized at 298 K and 5–200 bar,
which can deliver 31% more than the compressed natrual gas (CNG) process
at 200 bar and 12% more than the CNG process at 250 bar. Comparing
with all the reported methane uptake data up to 200 bar (b and ), this performance is a new record
in MOFs and surpasses the previous record holder of activated carbons.

elements.content: (a) Ultrahigh-pressure (0–200 bar) methane uptake isotherms for ST-2 at 283, 298, and 308 K. (b) Comparison of deliverable capacities (5–200 bar) of ST-2 to other MOF, carbon, polymer, and zeolite materials reported in the literature.

Deliverable capacity or working capacity is the usable amount of methane from the maximun adsorption operational pressure to the minum inlet pressure (5 bar) for pushing flow to the engine.

metadata.title:
Engineering
of Pore Geometry for Ultrahigh Capacity
Methane Storage in Mesoporous Metal–Organic Frameworks
